tr.td:
The patient is a 76-year-old female who presented to the emergency room yesterday afternoon with right sided abdominal pain. She notes that she has had at least a five day history of abdominal pain, if not longer. She presented to the emergency room with this abdominal pain. She was admitted to the hospital for observation. Her primary care physician is in South Bend. The patient's abdominal pain is right sided, constant and sharp. She has been nauseated and has been vomiting. She has had chills and fever. She states her bowel movements are okay. She has not had any diarrhea. She has been able to eat, but she has never had abdominal pain like this in the past.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, urinary incontinence and history of coronary artery disease. She also has a history of degenerative disc disease and anxiety.
MEDICATIONS: 1. Aspirin 81 mg p.o. daily. 2. Inderal 40 mg p.o. b.i.d. 3. Potassium 10 mEq p.o. daily. 4. Prinzide 20/25 one p.o. daily. 5. Nexium 40 mg p.o. daily. 6. Niacin 500 mg p.o. daily. 7. Norco 10/325 one p.o. three times daily. 8. Norvasc 5 mg p.o. daily. 9. Oxybutynin 500 mg p.o. q.h.s. 10.Plavix 75 mg p.o. daily. 11.Xanax 1 mg p.o. three times daily. 12.Baclofen 10 mg p.o. three times daily. 13.Iodoral 12.5 mg once daily. That is apparently an over-the-counter potassium supplement.
ALLERGIES: MORPHINE and Amoxicillin.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
VITAL SIGNS: Temperature 97.6, pulse 62, respirations 20 and blood pressure 82/45.
GENERAL: On my exam, the patient is alert and oriented times three. Normocephalic, atraumatic. Mental status is appropriate. She is in no acute distress while at rest.
CARDIOVASCULAR: Regular rate and rhythm. Normal S1 and S2. No murmurs were auscultated.
LUNGS: Good breath sounds bilaterally. No crackles or wheezes. No respiratory distress.
ABDOMEN: Soft, nontender and nondistended. There is diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation. This is more noticeable on the right side however the whole abdomen has diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. The abdomen was again soft and nondistended.
EXTREMITIES: Lower extremities were without edema.
SKIN: Grossly free of rashes.
LABORATORY DATA: White count of 15.2. Her complete blood count showed her amylase was 52, which is not abnormal. Her complete metabolic profile was essentially unremarkable. Her sodium was 133, which is slightly low. On September 5th, the patient again had a normal amylase. Her metabolic profile showed a sodium of 134 and potassium of 3.4, which is very slightly off. Lipase was 44. Complete blood count again showed a white count of 15.5, hemoglobin of 14.2 and platelets of 462,000. Urine pregnancy test was negative. Urinalysis showed negative nitrites and negative leukocytes.
RADIOLOGY: She did have a CT of the abdomen and pelvis done on August 30th that showed a normal appendix, no abdominal or pelvic lymphadenopathy, no bowel obstruction, no free air or fluid within the abdomen, so it was a negative CT. On September 5th, acute abdominal series showed no acute intraabdominal or pelvic process. CT of abdomen and pelvis showed no acute abnormalities noted within the abdomen or pelvis. So it is best to note that in the past week the patient has had two CT's of the abdomen and pelvis, which have been negative for acute findings.
ASSESSMENT/PLAN: The patient is a very pleasant 76-year-old female who presents with a one week history of right sided abdominal pain. Her labs are significant only for a white count, which is slightly elevated at 15,000. This would be consistent with mild leukocytosis, which we do sometimes see in folks who smoke cigarettes. Her labs are otherwise unremarkable. Urinalysis was negative. She has had two CT's of her abdomen and pelvis, which have been negative. She does have some discomfort this morning, but she stated she was hungry and we did bring her some food, so we have advanced her to a regular diet this morning. She states she feels better and wants to go home this morning and I do not have any objective evidence of an acute or a malignant intraabdominal process. My plan this morning is to have her seen by Dr. Mathew. She will be evaluated, he will proceed with probably scheduling outpatient workup for her and then I would anticipate probably discharging her to home after that. I did reconcile her home medications and as stated above we will have her seen by Dr. Baxter and proceed with management after that.

My plan this morning is to have her seen by Dr. Mathew. She will be evaluated, he will proceed with probably scheduling outpatient workup for her and then I would anticipate probably discharging her to home after that. I did reconcile her home medications and as stated above we will have her seen by Dr. Baxter and proceed with management after that.

act.text: 780.52 F/U: Followup: as needed. 787.91 F/U: Followup:. (Follow up)
